questions.text: Which enzyme is known to contain the amino acid selenocysteine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione peroxidase

 

Option B:

 

Glutathione peroxidase is an enzyme that contains the rare amino acid selenocysteine at its active site. This enzyme is crucial for reducing lipid hydroperoxides to their corresponding alcohols and for reducing free hydrogen peroxide to water.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Glutathione reductase - This enzyme does not contain selenocysteine; it catalyzes the reduction of glutathione disulfide to the sulfhydryl form glutathione.

 

Option C: Thioredoxin peroxidase - Also known as peroxiredoxins, these do not typically contain selenocysteine.

 

Option D: Thioredoxin oxidase - This is not a commonly recognized enzyme with selenocysteine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selenocysteine (SeCys) is seen at the active site of the following enzymes:

 

  • Thioredoxin reductase
  • Glutathione peroxidase, which scavenges peroxides
  • Deiodinase that removes iodine from thyroxine to make triiodothyronine
  • Selenoprotein P, a glycoprotein seen in mammalian blood

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e p 215.

questions.text: Match the following metalloenzymes:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

 

Option A:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 51.

questions.text: Non-protein part of the enzyme can be
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All the above

 

Option D:

 

The non-protein components of enzymes can include coenzymes, cofactors, and prosthetic groups, each playing a vital role in the enzyme's catalytic activity:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Coenzymes: These are organic molecules, often derived from vitamins, that temporarily associate with the enzyme and participate in the reaction by transferring a chemical group from one molecule to another. They are not permanently bound to the enzyme and can be reused in multiple catalytic cycles.

 

Option B. Cofactors: This term encompasses a broader range of non-protein molecules that assist enzymes in their catalytic activity. Cofactors can be metal ions like magnesium, zinc, or iron, which are inorganic, or organic molecules, in which case they are also known as coenzymes. They can be either loosely attached or tightly bound to the enzyme.

 

Option C. Prosthetic groups: These are non-protein components that are tightly, often covalently, bound to the enzyme. They are permanent parts of the enzyme's structure and participate directly in the enzyme's catalytic process. Examples include heme in cytochromes and the biotin in enzymes involved in carboxylation reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enzymes can be of two types:
    • Simple Enzyme: Consists of only proteins.
    • Complex enzyme consists of: Protein part: Apoenzyme and Nonprotein part
  • Apoenzyme + Non Protein part (Prosthetic group/Cofactor/ Coenzyme) = Holoenzyme
  • Nonprotein parts can be Coenzyme, Cofactor and Prosthetic group.

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 50.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes, known for its critical role in both anaerobic and aerobic pathways by interconverting a three-carbon compound with its reduced form, contains the Rossmann fold associated NADH domain?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lactate Dehydrogenase    

 

Option D.

 

Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH) is an enzyme that catalyzes the interconversion of lactate and pyruvate, with the concomitant interconversion of NADH and NAD+, in both anaerobic and aerobic pathways. It is known to contain the Rossmann fold, a structural motif essential for NADH binding. This motif facilitates the enzyme's critical role in energy metabolism, especially under anaerobic conditions, such as during intense exercise when oxygen is scarce, and cells rely more on glycolysis for ATP production.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pyruvate Dehydrogenase: It is a multi-enzyme complex with 5 coenzymes and 3 apo-enzymes, which favours oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl CoA.

 

Option B. Isocitrate Dehydrogenase: It is a NAD linked dehydrogenase, which helps in dehydrogenation and decarboxylation of isocitrate to alpha ketoglutarate.

 

Option C. ALA dehydratase: Involved in heme synthesis.

 

OXIDOREDUCTASE GROUP OF ENZYMES WITH ROSSMAN FOLD

 

  • Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase
  • Malate dehydrogenase
  • Quinone oxidoreductase
  • 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase
  • D-glycerate dehydrogenase
  • Formate dehydrogenase

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 40.

questions.text: A research team is investigating the digestion of dietary proteins and employs chymotrypsin to understand the breakdown process. Chymotrypsin, a digestive enzyme, is known for its specificity in targeting peptide bonds. In assessing the activity of chymotrypsin, the team is particularly interested in identifying the amino acid residues that, when positioned at the carbonyl side of a peptide bond, are most susceptible to cleavage by this enzyme. Which amino acid residue is chymotrypsin most likely to cleave at the carbonyl terminal side of a peptide bond?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Phenylalanine

 

Option A.

 

Chymotrypsin selectively cleaves peptide bonds at the carbonyl terminal of aromatic amino acids, with phenylalanine being one of the preferred residues. This specificity is due to the enzyme's ability to accommodate the bulky aromatic side chains in its active site.

 

  • Serine Proteases are proteolytic enzymes with Serine at their active Site
  • Amino acid triad in the active site of Serine Proteases: Ser, His, Asp.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Arginine: While arginine is a basic amino acid with a significant role in various biochemical processes, chymotrypsin does not preferentially cleave at the carbonyl terminal of arginine residues.

 

Option C. Lysine: Similar to arginine, lysine is a basic amino acid. Chymotrypsin's specificity for aromatic side chains means it does not typically cleave peptide bonds at the carbonyl terminal of lysine residues.

 

Option D. Glycine: Glycine, being a small and flexible amino acid, does not fit the specificity profile of chymotrypsin, which favors larger, aromatic residues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examples of serine proteases

 

  • Chymotrypsin
  • Trypsin
  • Elastase
  • Thrombin
  • Plasmin
  • Complements
  • Factor X and XI.

 

Serine proteases differ in substrate specificity

 

  • Trypsin cleaves adjacent to Basic Amino Acid like Arg, Lys.
  • Chymotrypsin cleaves adjacent to Hydrophobic Bulky Amino Acid like Trp, Tyr, Phe
  • Elastase cleaves adjacent to Small neutral Amino Acids like Alanine, Glycine.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p 64.

questions.text: Among the listed enzymes, which one is NOT typically considered a non-functional enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lipoprotein lipase

 

Explanation:

 

Enzymes found in the plasma can be classified into two types:

 

Non-functional (plasma marker) enzymes:

  • These do not perform any physiological function in plasma.
  • Their presence in serum is typically due to cell damage or turnover.
  • Elevated levels help identify tissue injury or disease.
  • Examples:
    • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) – bone and liver disorders
    • Acid phosphatase – prostate conditions
    • Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) – hepatobiliary dysfunction
    • LDH, CK, AST – used as diagnostic markers

 

Functional (plasma active) enzymes:

  • These perform essential metabolic functions within the circulation.
  • They are actively secreted into plasma to carry out physiological roles.

 

Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is a classic functional enzyme:

  • It hydrolyzes triglycerides in chylomicrons and VLDL into free fatty acids and glycerol.
  • Plays a critical role in lipid metabolism and energy distribution.

 

Other Options:

  • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
    → Non-functional enzyme; diagnostic marker for bone and hepatobiliary diseases.
  • Acid phosphatase
    → Non-functional; historically used to detect prostate cancer.
  • Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)
    → Non-functional; useful in assessing alcoholic liver disease and cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lipoprotein lipase is a functional plasma enzyme, directly involved in lipid metabolism.
  • In contrast, non-functional enzymes like ALP, ACP, GGT do not have roles in the plasma but serve as important clinical markers of tissue damage.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 301.

questions.text: Match the cell organelle with its marker enzymes:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4-c

 

Option C:

 

Explanation

 

  • Plasma Membrane: The correct marker enzyme is 5’-nucleotidase (d). This enzyme is involved in the hydrolysis of nucleotides to nucleosides and is found in the plasma membrane, playing a role in signal transduction.
  • Golgi Bodies: Galactosyltransferase (a) is the marker enzyme for Golgi bodies. It is involved in the glycosylation of proteins, a process that occurs extensively within the Golgi apparatus.
  • Cytosol: Lactate dehydrogenase (b) is a marker for the cytosol. This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to lactate when oxygen is absent or in short supply, and it is predominantly found in the cytoplasm.
  • Lysosomes: Acid phosphatase (c) is the marker enzyme for lysosomes. It functions in the hydrolysis of phosphate monoesters under acidic conditions, a characteristic activity of the lysosomal digestive process.

 

Educational Objective

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 12.

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes mellitus, previously uncontrolled on oral hypoglycaemic agents, has been on insulin therapy for the past year. In the context of insulin's molecular structure and its therapeutic modifications, which of the following alterations will lead to Various short and long-acting analogs of the hormone ?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Change in 29-30 in B chain 

Option A: 

 Insulin's primary structure consists of two polypeptide chains: the A chain (21 amino acids) and the B chain (30 amino acids).  

There are two interchain disulfide bonds: 

  • Between the 7th amino acid of the A chain and the 7th amino acid of the B chain. 
  • Between the 20th amino acid of the A chain and the 19th amino acid of the B chain. One intrachain disulfide bond exists between the 6th and 11th amino acids of the A chain. 

 Modifications in amino acids 29-30 of the B chain result in the production of short- and long-acting insulin types, depending on the changes made 

Other Options Explanation: 

Option B. Change at positions 5-6 in the A chain: This region is crucial for maintaining the hormone's structural integrity, and alterations could disrupt its conformation and receptor binding. 

 

Option C. Hydrolysis of disulfide bonds: The disulfide bonds are essential for maintaining insulin's tertiary structure. Their hydrolysis would lead to a loss of structural integrity, significantly impacting biological activity. 

 

Option D. change in 14-16 in A chain: Changing the sequence in the A chain can disrupt the structure and function of insulin. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 512; Lippincott 7/e : P 308

questions.text: A young woman presents with abdominal bloating and diarrhea after eating ice cream, alongside physical signs of dehydration but normal body temperature. She has a history of similar symptoms following the consumption of substantial amounts of dairy products. What enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lactase

 

Option C:

 

  • The symptoms develop in the above case only after the ingestion of dairy products, hence the patient is deficient in lactase.
  • Lactase is present in the brush border of enterocytes, which hydrolyses lactose to glucose and galactose.
  • Deficiency of lactase → lactose intolerance → accumulation of lactose in the gut → Irritant diarrhoea and flatulence.
  • Treatment: Temporary withdrawal of milk, intake of curd as it contains lactobacillus and yeast (both has the enzyme lactase) could also be used in treatment.

 

  Explanation:

 

Option A.  Isomaltose: Deficiency in isomaltase, part of the enzyme complex that also includes sucrase, leads to isomaltose intolerance. While it can cause similar symptoms of malabsorption, the specific reaction to dairy products is more indicative of lactose intolerance.

 

Option B.  α-amylase: α-Amylase deficiency is exceedingly rare and would lead to a broader range of symptoms associated with the malabsorption of starches, not specifically dairy products.

 

Option D. Sucrase: Sucrase deficiency results in sucrase-isomaltase deficiency, which would lead to symptoms following the ingestion of sucrose and isomaltose-rich foods, not specifically lactose-containing foods like dairy products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lactose intolerance is a condition resulting from lactase deficiency, characterized by gastrointestinal symptoms such as bloating, diarrhea, and dehydration following the ingestion of lactose-containing foods like dairy products. Identifying the specific trigger (lactose) and connecting it to the deficient enzyme (lactase) is key in diagnosing and managing this condition effectively.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 537-538.

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT reduce the activation energy necessary for an enzymatic reaction to proceed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. competition between substrates

 

Option D.

 

 

  • An activation barrier, representing the transition state, must be overcome in order to convert reactants (A) into products (B), even though the products are more stable than the reactants, as indicated by a large, negative free-energy change (ΔG) {Option (a)}.
  • The energy required to overcome such an activation barrier is the activation energy (ΔG‡).
  • Enzymes catalyze reactions by lowering the activation barrier. They bind the transition state intermediates tightly, and the binding energy of this interaction effectively reduces the activation energy from ΔG‡ uncat to ΔG‡ cat.
  • Prominent physical and thermodynamic factors contributing to ΔG‡, the barrier to reaction, might include
  1. A reduction in entropy {Option (b)}, in the form of decreased freedom of motion of two molecules in solution;
  2. Solvation shell of hydrogen-bonded water that surrounds and helps to stabilize most biomolecules in aqueous solution {Option (c)}   
  3. Distortion of substrates that must occur in many reactions.
  4. Need for proper alignment of catalytic functional groups on the enzyme.
  • Binding energy can be used to overcome all these barriers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Negative free energy change (ΔG): A negative ΔG indicates a reaction that can occur spontaneously, which is generally associated with processes that do not require an increase in activation energy.

 

Option B. Reducing entropy: By reducing entropy, enzymes organize the reactants into a specific orientation that facilitates the reaction, effectively lowering the activation energy.

 

Option C. Desolvation of the enzyme’s active site: Desolvation can help in stabilizing the transition state and decrease activation energy by reducing the energy needed for the reaction to proceed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Activation energy is the energy barrier that must be overcome for a reaction to proceed. Enzymes work by lowering this barrier, thereby increasing the rate of the reaction. Competition between substrates for the active site does not lower the activation energy; instead, it can lead to a decrease in the rate of reaction if one substrate outcompetes another for enzyme binding.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:p 77, Lippincott 7/e :P 55, 56, Leininger : 194-200.

choices.text: Most of enzymes are proteins
They contain 16% weight as nitrogen

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic commonly associated with enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Water-insoluble

 

Option C.

 

The incorrect statement here is that enzymes are water insoluble. Enzymes, being proteins for the most part, are typically water-soluble, which allows them to function effectively in the aqueous environment of the body's cells and fluids. Their solubility is crucial for their ability to catalyze biochemical reactions in living organisms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Most enzymes are proteins: This is a true characteristic of enzymes. While there are some RNA molecules (ribozymes) that exhibit catalytic properties, the vast majority of enzymes are indeed proteins.

 

Option B. Enzymes are heat labile: This is also true. Enzymes, like most proteins, are sensitive to heat, which can denature them, leading to a loss of their three-dimensional structure and catalytic activity.

 

Option D. Enzymes contain approximately 16% of their weight as nitrogen: This statement is generally true for proteins, including enzymes, due to the presence of amino acids, which contain nitrogen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Characteristics of Enzymes:

 

  • Almost all enzymes are proteins and follow the physical and chemical reactions of proteins. Some enzymes are also made of RNA known as ribozymes.
  • They are heat labile.
  • Most of them are water-soluble.
  • They can be precipitated by protein precipitating reagents (ammonium sulfate or trichloroacetic acid).
  • They contain 16% weight as nitrogen

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 48.

questions.text: What is the classification of chymotrypsinogen based on its functional state before activation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Zymogen

 

  • Zymogen activation is an example of irreversible covalent Modification.
  • A type of enzyme activation is the conversion of an inactive pro-enzyme or zymogen to the active enzyme. Following are few e.g:
  • By splitting a single peptide bond and removal of a small polypeptide from trypsinogen, the active trypsin is formed exposing the active centre.
  • Trypsin activates chymotrypsinogen  → forms A peptide (1–13 A.A), B peptide (16–46 A.A) and C peptide (149–245 A.A) → align to form active site in histidine (57) and aspartate (102) and serine (195).
  • All G.I enzymes are synthesized in the form of pro-enzymes  → after secretion into the alimentary canal get activated  → prevents autolysis of cellular structural proteins.
  • Activation of coagulation factors
  • Activation of complement components

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chymotrypsinogen is a zymogen, which is an inactive precursor of an enzyme. Zymogens are converted into their active forms through a biochemical change, typically the cleavage of specific peptide bonds. In the case of chymotrypsinogen, it is activated to become chymotrypsin, a key enzyme in protein digestion.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 59.

questions.text: it's important to recognize enzymes that are synthesized in an inactive form within living cells and later activated through various biochemical processes. What term is used to describe these initially inactive forms of enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Proenzymes

 

Option D.

 

  • Enzyme activation is the conversion of an inactive pro-enzyme or zymogen to the active enzyme.
  • By splitting a single peptide bond and removal of a small polypeptide from trypsinogen, the active trypsin is formed exposing the active centre.
  • Trypsin activates chymotrypsinogen → forms A peptide (1–13 A.A), B peptide (16–46 A.A) and C peptide (149–245 A.A) → align to form active site in histidine (57) and aspartate (102) and serine (195).
  • All G.I enzymes are synthesized in the form of pro-enzymes → after secretion into the alimentary canal get activated → prevents autolysis of cellular structural proteins.
  • Activation of coagulation factors.
  • Activation of complement components.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Papain: Is a therapeutic enzyme used as an anti-inflammatory agent and it is a cysteine protease.

 

Option B. Lysozymes: It has a repeating hexasaccharide unit and a combination of substrate strain and acid base catalysis is noted in the action of lysozyme. This mechanism contributes to the antibactericidal action of lysozymes.

 

Option C. Apoenzymes: In compound proteins, the protein component is ‘Apoenzyme’ and the prosthetic group is ‘coenzyme’. The combination produces a functional ‘holoenzyme’.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proenzymes, also known as zymogens, are inactive precursors of enzymes. They require a biochemical change, such as the cleavage of specific peptide bonds, to become active. This mechanism ensures that enzymes are activated only when and where they are needed, preventing potential damage to the cell or tissue from premature enzymatic activity.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 59.

questions.text: In the context of enzymatic activity and biological catalysts, which of the following non-protein substances is known to function as an enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ribozyme

 

Option B.

 

  • Ribozymes are non-protein, RNA molecules with enzymatic activity, which catalyse the sequence specific cleavage activity → cutting of nascent mRNA or primary transcript.
  • They exhibit Michaelis-Menten kinetics.
  • Examples: RNAse P, peptidyl transferase and spliceosomes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. DNA: While DNA stores and transmits genetic information, it is not known to have enzymatic activity under normal physiological conditions.

 

Option C. Phospholipid: Phospholipids are a major component of cell membranes and serve structural and functional roles in cells, but they do not have enzymatic activity.

 

Option D. Glycolipid: Glycolipids are components of the cell membrane that participate in cell recognition and signaling but are not enzymes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ribozymes are RNA molecules that have the ability to catalyze certain chemical reactions, functioning similarly to protein enzymes. They are unique among RNA molecules in that they are not merely substrates or products of reactions but active catalysts.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 65, 592.

questions.text: In the study of enzymatic functions within biological systems, various factors are known to influence enzyme activity. Which of the following factors can affect the activity of enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

Enzyme activity can be influenced by a range of factors, including:

Negative modifiers, which can bind to enzymes and decrease their activity,

Changes in pH, as enzymes have optimal pH ranges and deviating from these ranges can alter the enzyme's structure and functionality,

Changes in temperature, which can increase enzyme activity up to a point but can lead to denaturation and loss of activity if the temperature is too high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factors Affecting Enzyme Activity:

 

  1. Enzyme concentration
  2. Substrate concentration
  3. Product concentration
  4.   Temperature
  5.   Hydrogen ion concentration (pH)
  6.   Presence of activators
  7.   Presence of inhibitors
  8.   Presence of repressor or derepressor
  9.   Covalent modification

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 56-59.

choices.text: The active site is complementary in shape to that of substance only after interaction
The active site is complementary in shape to that of substrate
Substrates change confirmation prior to active site interaction
The active site is flexible and adjusts to substrate

questions.text: In exploring the fundamental concepts of enzyme-substrate interaction, the 'lock and key' model proposed by Emil Fischer provides an analogy to understand enzyme specificity. According to this model, what is implied about the relationship between the enzyme's active site and the substrate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The active site is complementary in shape to that of substrate

 

Fischer’s Template Theory

 

Option B.

 

  • It states that the three-dimensional structure of the active site of the enzyme is complementary to the substrate. Thus enzyme and its substrate fit each other.
     

 

  • Substrate fits on the enzyme, similar to lock and key. The lock can be opened only by its specific key.
  • However, Fischer envisaged a rigid structure for enzymes, which could not explain the flexibility shown by enzymes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The active site is complementary in shape to that of the substrate only after interaction: This description more closely aligns with the 'induced fit' model, where the active site undergoes a conformational change upon substrate binding.

 

Option C. Substrates change confirmation prior to active site interaction: This is not a feature of the 'lock and key' model, which suggests a static, pre-determined fit between enzyme and substrate.

 

Option D. The active site is flexible and adjusts to the substrate: This concept is again representative of the 'induced fit' model, not the 'lock and key' model.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fischer's 'lock and key' model posits that the enzyme's active site has a specific geometric shape that is exactly complementary to the shape of the substrate, much like a lock is to a key. This model emphasizes the specificity of enzyme-substrate interactions, suggesting that enzymes can only bind to substrates that fit perfectly into their active sites.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 358.

questions.text: In a recent journal club meeting, a discussion arose around the adaptability of enzyme active sites upon substrate binding. A new member presented a model that suggests the active site of an enzyme is not rigid but can mold itself to fit the shape of the substrate, enhancing the enzyme-substrate interaction. Which model describes this concept where the enzyme's active site undergoes a conformational change to accommodate the substrate more effectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Induced fit model

 

Option B.

 

Induced fit theory: Enzyme has shallow grooves and the substrate alignment is not correct. Fixing of the substrate induces structural changes in the enzyme. Now, the substrate correctly fits into the active site of the enzyme. Substrate is changed into products.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lock and key model: This earlier model suggests that the enzyme and substrate fit together perfectly without any need for adjustment, similar to a lock and its key. It does not account for flexibility in the enzyme's structure.

 

Option C. Fisher’s Template theory: This is essentially another name for the lock and key model proposed by Emil Fischer. It emphasizes a rigid, pre-formed shape of the enzyme's active site that perfectly matches the substrate, without considering conformational changes upon binding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The induced fit model proposes that the enzyme's active site is flexible and undergoes a conformational change upon substrate binding, enhancing the complementarity between the enzyme and substrate. This model accounts for the dynamic nature of enzyme-substrate interactions.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 53.

questions.text: Which of the following theory/model explains the mode of action of enzyme mentioned in the picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Induced fit model

 

Option A.

 

Koshland’s induced fit theory.

 

  1. Enzyme have shallow grooves and the substrate alignment is not correct.
  2. Fixing of substrates induces structural changes in enzyme.
  3. Now, the substrate correctly fits into the active site of the enzyme.
  4. Substrate is converted into products

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Michaelis–Menten model: Enzyme-Substrate complex theory-The enzyme (E) combines with the substrate (S) → enzyme-substrate (ES) complex → immediately breaks down to the enzyme and the product (P).

                    E + S → E–S Complex → E + P

 

Option C. Lock and key model: Fischer’s Template Theory- This theory states that the three-dimensional structures of the active site of the enzyme is complementary to the substrate → [E] and [S] fit each other similar to lock and key.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lineweaver-Burk plot is a double reciprocal graphical representation of the Michaelis-Menten equation. However, the Michaelis-Menten model assumes that the enzyme-substrate complex is static and does not account for changes in the enzyme structure upon substrate binding. In contrast, the induced fit model posits that the enzyme structure is flexible and changes to accommodate the substrate upon binding, which is not directly observable in a Lineweaver-Burk plot.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 53.

choices.text: It forms the half of the potion of enzyme
It binds with substrate by non-covalent bonds
It is not usually a cleft or crevices
Binding of substrate to the site is independent of the alignment of specific groups.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes a key aspect of the active site of an enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It binds with substrate by non-covalent bonds

 

Option B.

 

The active site of an enzyme is the region where substrate molecules bind and undergo a chemical reaction. This binding is typically achieved through non-covalent interactions such as hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, van der Waals forces, and hydrophobic interactions. These interactions ensure that the substrate is precisely aligned in the active site, facilitating the catalytic process while allowing for the substrate's release after the reaction.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It forms half of the portion of the enzyme: This statement is inaccurate. The active site usually comprises only a small portion of the enzyme's total volume, specifically tailored for substrate binding and catalysis.

 

Option C. It is not usually a cleft or crevice: Contrary to this statement, the active site is often a cleft or crevice on the enzyme's surface. This structural feature allows the active site to accommodate the substrate molecule(s) and exclude water, which is crucial for many enzymatic reactions.

 

Option D. Binding of the substrate to the site is independent of the alignment of specific groups: This statement is incorrect. The binding of the substrate to the active site is highly dependent on the precise alignment and orientation of specific amino acid residues and functional groups within the active site. This specificity ensures that only particular substrates can bind and be catalytically transformed by the enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. The region of the enzyme where substrate binding and catalysis takes place is known as active site or active centre and it contains substrate binding site and catalytic site.
  2. Though all parts are required for maintaining the three-dimensional structure of the enzyme, the reaction is taking place at the active site and it occupies only a small portion of the whole enzyme.
  3. Active site is situated in a crevice or cleft of the enzyme molecule.
  4. To the active site, substrate is bound and the binding depends on the alignment of specific groups or atoms at active site and these groups realign themselves to provide the unique conformational orientation so as to promote exact fitting of substrate to the active site.
  5. The substrate binds to the enzyme at the active site by noncovalent bonds and are hydrophobic in nature.
  6. The amino acids or groups which directly participate in making or breaking the bonds (present at the active site) are known as catalytic residues or catalytic groups.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 55.

questions.text: A 35-year-old researcher is conducting a study on the catalytic rates of various enzymes in metabolic pathways. She is comparing the activities of different enzymes under standardized conditions and intends to express these activities in a uniform manner to facilitate comparison. She recalls that there is an SI unit for expressing enzyme activity, but she is momentarily uncertain of its name. Which of the following is the correct SI unit for expressing enzyme activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Katals

 

Option B.

 

Katals is the correct answer. The katal is the SI unit for catalytic activity and is used to express the amount of enzyme needed to catalyze the conversion of one mole of substrate per second under specified conditions. This unit is particularly useful in biochemistry for quantifying the efficiency and comparing the catalytic activities of different enzymes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Micromoles: This is a measure of the amount of substance, not the rate of enzymatic activity. While enzyme activities can result in the conversion of substrates measured in micromoles, this is not a unit of enzyme activity.

 

Option C. Units: This term is often used in biochemistry, but it is not a standardized SI unit. One unit (U) is traditionally defined as the amount of enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of 1 micromole of substrate per minute, but it lacks the universal applicability and consistency of katals.

 

Option D. Moles per second: While this could theoretically be used to describe enzyme activity, it is not the standard SI unit for this purpose. The katal is specifically defined as moles per second, making it the preferred and standardized term.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Catalytic efficiency is expressed as the ratio of Kcat divided by Km, by what measure should the efficiency of different enzymes, different substrates for a given enzyme, and the efficiency with which an enzyme catalyzes a reaction in the forward and reverse directions be quantified and compared.

 

  • Enzyme activity is expressed as micromoles of substrate converted to product per minute under specified assay conditions.
  • One standard unit (or International Unit) of enzyme activity (U): amount of enzyme that will convert one micromole of substrate per minute per litre of sample and is abbreviated as U/L
  • The modern method of expression of enzyme activity is in Katals (kat).
  • One Katal (catalytic activity) is defined as the number of mol of substrate transformed per second per litre of sample (Kcat = Vmax divided by the number of active sites).

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 80, Lippincott 7/e: P 54.

choices.text: Is also called mixed function oxidase
Associated with smooth endoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: A clinical discussion focuses on the metabolism of drugs and the body's detoxification pathways. One topic of interest is the cytochrome P450 enzyme system and its various characteristics. Participants are asked to identify which statement about cytochrome P450 is incorrect based on its known properties and functions:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Is an allosteric enzyme

 

Option D:

 

  • The cytochrome P450 enzymes are involved in the biotransformation reactions.
  • They are heme-containing enzymes, localized in the endoplasmic reticulum of the liver and has about 150 isoforms of the P450 enzymes.
  • They are so called, because they absorb light at a wavelength of 450 nm, when exposed to carbon monoxide.
  • They are mono-oxygenase and NADPH is the coenzyme for all the P450 enzymes. Thus, electrons are transferred from NADPH to cytochrome P450 à leads to the reductive activation of molecular oxygen.
  • Microsomal Ethanol Oxidizing System (MEOS) is another mechanism of detoxification of alcohol which is cytochrome P450 dependent and is inducible

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Is also known as mixed function oxidase: This statement is accurate. Cytochrome P450 enzymes are sometimes referred to as mixed-function oxidases due to their ability to introduce one atom of oxygen into a substrate while reducing the other atom to water.

 

Option B. Utilizes NADPH in its enzymatic reactions: This is true. Cytochrome P450 enzymes use NADPH as a coenzyme to donate electrons for their enzymatic reactions.

 

Option C. Is located primarily in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum: This statement is correct. Many cytochrome P450 enzymes are found in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum, where they play a role in the metabolism of endogenous and exogenous substances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cytochrome P450 enzymes exhibit a wide substrate range and are integral to the metabolic processes within the smooth endoplasmic reticulum using NADPH, they are not characterized by allosteric regulation.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 478, 479
